abstract: General Electric is getting out of the subprime mortgage market by selling WMC Mortgage, the company announced on Thursday.
snippet: General Electric is getting out of the subprime mortgage market by selling WMC Mortgage, the company announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: General Electric will abandon the subprime mortgage market by selling the company’s unit that makes loans to borrowers with weak credit histories. The decision to sell the unit, WMC Mortgage, was announced by the company yesterday in an e-mail message to employees, and confirmed by a person who had read it.

headline.main: General Electric to Sell WMC Mortgage, a Subprime Loan Unit
headline.print_headline: General Electric to Sell WMC Mortgage, a Subprime Loan Unit

abstract: Fitch Ratings said it might downgrade bonds valued at $7.1 billion due to rising delinquencies and defaults on subprime mortgages.
snippet: Fitch Ratings said it might downgrade bonds valued at $7.1 billion due to rising delinquencies and defaults on subprime mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Fitch Ratings, the credit ratings agency, said yesterday that it might downgrade bonds valued at $7.1 billion because of rising delinquencies and defaults on subprime mortgages.

headline.main: Fitch May Downgrade Bonds Tied to Subprime Mortgages
headline.print_headline: Fitch May Downgrade Bonds Tied to Subprime Mortgages

abstract: IGA Worldwide netted $25 million in Series B fuding in a round led by KTB Ventures and Peacock Equity, a joint venture between General Electric Media, Communications and Entertainment and NBC Universal.
lead_paragraph: IGA Worldwide netted $25 million in Series B fuding in a round led by KTB Ventures and Peacock Equity, a joint venture between General Electric Media, Communications and Entertainment and NBC Universal.
